item.title: JONSNOW
item.description: JONSNOW

item.title: Extremists to be put in special prison units
item.description: Extremist prisoners who "seek to poison the minds of others" will be put in special units in England and Wales, Justice Secretary Liz Truss says.

item.title: Three rescues for holidaymaker cut off by Cornwall tide
item.description: A young woman holidaying in Cornwall is rescued by the same lifeboat crew three times in four days after being cut off by the tide.

item.title: Briton 'dies defusing Islamic State bomb' in Iraq
item.description: A British citizen has been killed in Iraq trying to defuse a bomb left by the so-called Islamic State group, US contractor Janus says.

item.title: Fatal dog attack man David Ellam 'loved' volunteering
item.description: The family of a man killed by a dog says he was a passionate Huddersfield Town FC fan who spent his spare time volunteering.

item.title: Rio Olympics 2016: Team GB medal haul makes them a 'superpower of sport'
item.description: Britain's Rio medal haul makes them a "superpower of Olympic sport", says UK Sport chief executive Liz Nicholl.

item.title: Man 'assaulted teens over cuddle' in east London street
item.description: A "bully" grabs a schoolboy by the throat and calls his girlfriend a "whore" after spotting them cuddling in east London, a court hears.

item.title: Lord Heseltine: Theresa May won't ditch plan for mayors
item.description: Former Deputy Prime Minister Lord Heseltine dismisses reports Theresa May could "kill off" George Osborne's elected mayor project.

item.title: Labour leadership: Ballot papers for contest being sent out
item.description: The two candidates to become Labour leader urge members to back them as ballot papers begin to be sent to nearly 650,000 people.

item.title: Lecturer admits killing wife in 'stabbing frenzy' as children slept
item.description: A college lecturer admits killing his wife in "a stabbing frenzy" after wrongly believing he was not the father of their two children.

item.title: Dee Fennell granted bail variation for holiday
item.description: A prominent dissident republican, facing trial over charges of encouraging terrorism, has his bail conditions changed so he can go on holiday.

item.title: Pioneering TV weatherman Trevor Baker dies aged 94
item.description: Pioneering TV weatherman Trevor Baker has died at the age of 94, ITV announces.

item.title: Team GB makes history: Watch the highlights
item.description: Team GB is second in the Rio Olympics medals table - watch some of the highlights.

item.title: Penguin inspects King of Norwayâ€™s Guard
item.description: A penguin at Edinburgh Zoo inspects the King of Norway's Guard for whom is mascot.

item.title: Toxic shock warning: Toddler lost legs after misdiagnosis
item.description: A mother is keen to raise awareness of toxic shock syndrome after her son's case was misdiagnosed as tonsillitis.

item.title: Labour leadership contest in numbers
item.description: BBC News looks at the Labour leadership contest in numbers.

item.title: Meet the professional online gambler
item.description: Donald, 26, talks through his day as an professional online poker player and explains why he doesn't think it has a future.

item.title: Black door appears on Berkshire bridge
item.description: A mysterious black door has appeared on Sonning bridge, puzzling nearby residents.

item.title: Unseasonably stormy weather behind UK sea deaths
item.description: Coastguards are warning people to stay a safe distance from rough seas after six people died around Britain.

item.title: BBC News Channel
item.description: Britain's most-watched news channel, delivering breaking news and analysis all day, every day.

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing: Greg Rutherford, Lesley Joseph and Tameka Empson to compete
item.description: Long jump star Greg Rutherford, actress Lesley Joseph and EastEnders actress Tameka Empson complete this year's Strictly Come Dancing line-up.

item.title: Car comes to rest on roof of Fiat 500 in Glasgow
item.description: Police were called to an unusual sight in Glasgow's west end over the weekend after an unoccupied car ended up on the roof of another vehicle.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Golden memories from GB's Olympics success
item.description: Team GB's success at the Rio Olympics dominates the front pages, while debate about the economic consequences of Brexit also appears.

item.title: Silent revolution
item.description: Panorama's Richard Bilton meets the people stepping in to keep services running in his local town of Selby after deep cuts in spending.

item.title: Spider silk
item.description: Spider silk is used to create a superlens for a microscope, allowing Bangor University scientists to view objects previously deemed "invisible".

item.title: Swiss role
item.description: Brexit complicates Swiss efforts to reach a deal with the EU on immigration, the BBC's Imogen Foulkes writes.

item.title: â€˜Respect the water'
item.description: Six people died around the UK and Channel Islands coastline in a series of incidents at the weekend - so can people stay safe at the coast?

item.title: Historic 'cots' sail again
item.description: A race involving traditional wooden boats takes place on Lough Erne for the first time in more than a century

item.title: Well qualified
item.description: Wimbledon underdog Marcus Willis coaches at his home tennis club for the first time since playing seven-times winner Roger Federer.

item.title: Air crash survivors
item.description: One year on from the Shoreham air crash, survivors have been recalling their experiences.

item.title: Essex dilemma
item.description: Large container ships passing close to the site of a historically significant shipwreck have caused its condition to deteriorate rapidly in the last year, divers say.

item.title: The big choke
item.description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan says Oxford Street is the world's most polluted road. Is he right?
